intro: Foeniculum vulgare subsp. sativum, commonly known as cumin, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It features feathery, aromatic leaves and produces small, yellowish-green flowers that develop into oval, seed-filled pods. The plant grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soils with full sun exposure. Its seeds, which are the primary part used in cooking, are harvested when dry and mature. Cumin is widely cultivated for its aromatic seeds and has been used for centuries in various cuisines and traditional medicine.
